awd_titl_txt: Developing a new proxy for silicate weathering: an investigation of Potassium isotope fractionation during clay formation
awd_abstract_narration:
New analytical methods have allowed the investigators to demonstrate that the potassium (K) isotope composition of the continents and the oceans are different.  Because the ultimate source of K delivered to the oceans is the weathering of continental rocks, there must be significant K isotope fractionation during chemical weathering and/or the cycling of K in the oceans by formation of K bearing minerals during the interaction of seawater with marine sediments/rocks. Researchers propose to study and quantify the exchange kinetics and fractionations of K isotopes during cation exchange and clay formation processes through a series of laboratory experiments and new high precision analyses of geologic samples. This work will provide an essential first step toward a wide range of potential applications of stable K isotopes in surficial environments, particularly, as a new silicate weathering proxy.  Such studies are critical for understanding the interplay between silicate weathering, atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, and past climatic changes. To highlight this contribution to young K-12 students, investigators will partner with the University of Wisconsin Geology Museum (UWGM;  www.geologymuseum.org), the most popular science-outreach venue on campus, to educate and communicate about continental weathering and the carbon cycle. UWGM Assistant Director Brooke Norsted will spearhead the Museum's involvement by creating the content and deliverables as well as overseeing their implementation.  Second, K is an essential nutrient for plant growth, and K isotopes in plants can be highly fractionated. The investigators will explore K nutrition in plant growth by conducting an undergraduate research class project by partnering with the UW Soil Science Department and students that take Soil Science 326, Plant Nutrition Management.  In this class students grow plants under K deficient and sufficient conditions to identify how K availability effects plant growth; the goal will be to evaluate if these nutrient conditions cause K isotopic fractionation and to demonstrate to the class the advantages of isotope analyses to tracing nutrient utilization.

The proposed research is to develop the stable K isotope system as a new silicate weathering proxy. Potassium as a major element participates widely in low temperature biogeochemical processes. Recent analytical advances have allowed the investigators to identify small but significant variations of delta 41/39K in terrestrial samples for the first time. The proposed work is motivated by existing data that show river waters and seawater have higher delta41K values as compared to a relatively homogeneous delta41K value of the bulk silicate earth. Available delta41K results indicate that cation-exchange and clay formation are the most likely mechanisms responsible for stable K isotope fractionations on the continents and in the ocean. The proposed experimental work centers on quantifying the exchange kinetics and fractionation of K isotopes during cation exchange and clay formation processes through a series of laboratory experiments, combined with new analyses of natural samples.  These data will provide an interpretive framework for low-temperature K isotope fractionations due to clays. Furthermore, this NSF-sponsored research will be integrated with NASA-funded experimental studies on Fe, Si, and Mg isotope fractionations associated with clays, paving the way for a multi-isotope approach for weathering processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The world's oceans have a K isotope composition ~0.6? heavier as compared to bulk silicate earth.  We have constrained the K isotope composition of all the inputs into seawater (K from rivers and mid ocean ridge hydrothermal systems) as part of this research project and these are not heavy enough to produce the K isotope composition of seawater.  The experiments we conducted show that K isotope exchange with clays produces aqueous K with heavier isotope composition because the clay preferentially sequesters 39K as compared to 41K and that isotope exchange can aid in producing the heavy K isotope composition of the oceans.  However, the magnitude of this fractionation is not large enough to produce the heavy K isotope composition of seawater.  We suspect that the process of clay formation that structurally incorporates K may more strongly fractionate K isotopes as compared to simple exchange.  We have conducted isotope tracer experiments on illite which shows that 95% of structural K in clay does not exchange making it possible that the structural incorporation of K during clay formation may produce large K isotope fractionations.

 

Additionally we have developed isotopic methods to constrain K fertilizer uptake by plants. This was done by growing corn in soil that was amended with different amounts of K fertilizer that had a grossly different K isotope composition as compared to the K isotope composition of the soil. This K isotope method shows great potential in improving our fundamental understanding of the dynamics of K exchange among different soil pools and many complex soil?plant?fertilizer interactions that were difficult to investigate using conventional methods. This effort is an important part of "broader impacts" of the project for several reasons. First, it represents a successful interdisciplinary collaboration between isotope geochemistry and agronomy. Second, the project was implemented through the labs of classroom teaching (Soil Science 626 Mineral Nutrition of Plants at UW-Madison), providing unique learning experience that exposed students in soil sciences department to the state-of-the-art isotope geochemistry research. Finally, it provides a novel approach for future research on K nutrient cycle, and this approach can be useful for multiple disciplines, ranging from soil sciences to plant sciences.
